column4: as far as i know you may only be able to do that in windows unless your bios manufacturer provided linux files to create or run a bios update. this isn't anything ubuntu/linux has control over sadly
, im trying to follow a mix of two tutorials i ve found in the net but unfortunately i dont have the knowledge enough i suppose
link me those tutorials i would like to look them over. a bios update is vendor specific (hp,dell, or mobo manufacturer) so it should be an interesting trick if someone has a workaround
http://www.linuxinsight.com/how-to-flash-motherboard-bios-from-linux-no-dos-windows-no-floppy-drive.html
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=802782
you have a fdd and a disk still? or you trying to apply this to a usb drive ?
, im trying to apply it to a floppy drive
what commands in that first tutorial are giving you trouble?
, the unmounting one , im not able to see the created directory
is the device still mounted? run just "mount" and look for /tmp/floppy in that list
also nuclearworm can you copy and paste the exact error the umount command gives you?
, i havent explained me well, after unmounting i couldn t see /tmp/floppy anymore so ive runned the first command again maybe i shouldn t have done that
o that is a natural side effect of umounting /tmp/floppy
when you issue that umount command it is going to save the changes back into that fdoem.144 file
so now you need to either write fdoem.144 to a cd or a floppy
my guess for a floppy you would do: dd if=/path/to/FDOEM.144.gz of=/dev/fd0
, so is the fdoem.144 changed , i mean does it have the added files?
yes if you issued the copy commands to put the files you need into the image
prior to umount'ing the virtual device
nenel audio and video are broad topics what are you looking for specifically
, ok  im going to try what you ve told me , thanks
gl have fun
